Question Text: Which of the following are examples of control plane operations? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Rate-limiting traffic so that the overall sending rate does not exceed a certain throughput.
b. Determining that a user's MAC address is authentic before allowing it to send traffic on the network.
c. Load balancing traffic across two output ports based on the hash of each packet's source IP address.
d. Determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy.
e. Computing a shortest path routing tree.
LLM Explanation: Control plane operations involve making decisions about how to handle network traffic. From the given choices, determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy (d) and computing a shortest path routing tree (e) are control plane functions. They involve making high-level decisions about traffic forwarding based on policies and routing algorithms. The other options describe data plane operations - rate limiting (a), MAC authentication (b), and load balancing (c) all involve processing and forwarding individual packets based on pre-determined rules, which is the role of the data plane.

Question Text: What could be the operational steps behind the AT&T's IRSCP (a commercial version of the Routing Control Platform) for detecting malicious traffic? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The controller sees all traffic passing through the network, detects an attack, and installs a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where the attack traffic is originating.
b. The end host changes its IP address so that it is no longer the target of the attack traffic.
c. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device.
d. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating.
e. A victim end host sends an alert to an on-path firewall about the source and nature of an attack, at which point the firewall installs a null route to drop the traffic at the entry point where the attack is originating.
LLM Explanation: The correct steps for AT&T's IRSCP in detecting and mitigating malicious traffic are:c) A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device. This allows for further analysis of the malicious traffic.d) A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating. This prevents the malicious traffic from propagating further into the network.The other options are incorrect because:a) The controller does not see all traffic and directly install null routes. b) The end host changing its IP does not resolve the attack at a network level.e) The end host does not directly interact with and instruct an on-path firewall.

Question Text: What are some example network management applications that become easier with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Improved interdomain routing security.
b. Customer-controlled egress selection.
c. Improved logging capabilities.
d. Planned maintenance of an edge router.
e. Forecasting of network capacity.
LLM Explanation: With the separation of control and data planes in SDN, certain network management tasks become easier. Customer-controlled egress selection (b) is simplified because the control plane has a global network view and can optimize egress point selection based on customer policies. Planned maintenance of an edge router (d) is also easier since the control plane can proactively reroute traffic away from the router to be serviced, minimizing disruption. While SDN may provide some benefits for the other options listed, they are not as directly impacted by control and data plane separation specifically.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'SDN: Software Defined Networks by Thomas D. Nadeau and Ken Gray']

Question Text: What are some of the motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Ability to use existing routing protocols to establish paths between hosts.
b. Easier configuration/administration, since there is no need to number hosts or configure subnets.
c. Better security properties.
d. Better scaling properties.
e. Better load balancing properties.
LLM Explanation: The main motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center are:b) Easier configuration and administration, since there is no need to assign IP addresses to hosts or configure IP subnets. With Layer-2 forwarding, hosts can be plugged in and automatically start communicating without additional IP configuration.d) Better scaling properties. Layer-2 forwarding allows the creation of very large Layer-2 domains that can span an entire data center. This avoids the need to segment the network into smaller IP subnets, which can be administratively complex as the data center grows.The other options are not strong motivations:a) Layer-2 forwarding does not use routing protocols. c) Layer-2 forwarding does not inherently provide better security than Layer-3 IP forwarding.e) Load balancing is typically done at higher layers and is independent of Layer-2 vs Layer-3 forwarding.

Question Text: How does the separation of the control and data plane make networking in data centers easier?
Choices:
a. Virtual machines can be migrated within the network without renumbering entire portions of the network or re-assigning network services to different IP addresses.
b. The control plane allows traffic to be forwarded using Layer 2 addresses, thus allowing automatic load balance across the topology.
c. The separation allows fewer switches to be used in the data center topology, thus lowering costs.
d. All routes can be controlled and monitored from a central point of control.
e. A network controller can permit the renumbering of end hosts to have topology-dependent Layer 2 MAC addresses.
LLM Explanation: The separation of control and data planes in software-defined networking (SDN) allows for easier management of data center networks in two key ways:  a) Virtual machines can be migrated within the network without the need to renumber IP addresses or reassign network services, because the SDN controller maintains a logical view of the network separate from the underlying physical infrastructure. This enables greater flexibility in workload placement and mobility.  d) Having a logically centralized control plane allows all routes and network policies to be managed and monitored from a single point of control, rather than having to configure each network device individually. This simplifies network operations and troubleshooting.  The other options are incorrect: b) The data plane still forwards traffic based on IP addresses at Layer 3, not Layer 2 MAC addresses.  c) SDN does not necessarily reduce the number of physical switches needed. e) Hosts still retain their original MAC addresses which are independent of network topology.
URLs: ['https://www.opennetworking.org/sdn-definition/', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/data-center-virtualization/what-is-sdn.html', 'Kreutz, D., Ramos, F., Verissimo, P., Rothenberg, C. E., Azodolmolky, S., & Uhlig, S. (2015). Software-defined networking: A comprehensive survey. Proceedings of the IEEE, 103(1), 14-76.']

Question Text: What are some examples of problems that can arise from consistency problems in the control plane, where a network has multiple controller replicas?
Choices:
a. A flood of traffic at the controller.
b. Inability to respond to link failures.
c. Incorrect security policies.
d. Incorrect operation when one controller fails.
e. Forwarding loops.
LLM Explanation: Inconsistency between controller replicas in the control plane can lead to several issues. It can cause inability to respond to link failures if the controllers have inconsistent network state information (b). Inconsistent security policies may get applied if the controllers are out of sync (c). If one controller fails, the remaining controllers may operate incorrectly due to inconsistencies (d). Forwarding loops can occur if flow rules programmed by different controllers conflict with each other (e). While a flood of traffic at the controller (a) is a potential SDN issue, it is not a direct consequence of control plane inconsistency.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 5 - The SDN Control Plane', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Principles_and_Practices_for_Securing_Software-Defined_Networks_applied_to_OFv1.3.4_V1.0.pdf']

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with inconsistency across controller replicas? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Running a consistency protocol across controller replicas.
b. Keeping a "hot spare" replica that has a complete view of the network state.
c. Only keeping a subset of the network state in memory at any time.
d. Using different controllers for independent parts of the network.
e. Having multiple controllers install forwarding table entries on the same router and resolving the conflict on the router itself.
LLM Explanation: Two viable approaches to handling inconsistency across controller replicas in SDN are:a) Running a consistency protocol across the replicas to ensure they maintain the same network state. This allows active coordination.  d) Partitioning the network and having each controller responsible for an independent subset. This avoids consistency issues by eliminating overlap.The other options are not ideal:b) A hot spare does not actively coordinate consistency. c) Keeping partial state makes it harder to make correct control decisions.e) Having routers resolve conflicts pushes complexity to the data plane and can lead to unpredictable behavior.

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with scalability challenges associated with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane to reduce traffic at the controller.
b. Only performing control-plane operations for a limited set of network operations.
c. Eliminating redundant data structures.
d. Sending all traffic through the controller to minimize forwarding decisions that the routers and switches must make.
e. Running multiple controllers, and having each controller only manage a part of the network.
LLM Explanation: To cope with scalability challenges in SDN due to control and data plane separation, some approaches include:a) Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane. This reduces the need for switches to query the controller for every new flow, decreasing control plane traffic.  c) Eliminating redundant data structures between the control and data planes to improve efficiency.e) Distributing the control plane by running multiple controllers that each manage a portion of the network. This prevents the controller from being a single bottleneck.Choices b and d are incorrect. Limiting control plane operations to a subset would reduce functionality. Sending all traffic through the controller would overload it, not improve scalability.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 6 - Scalability', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Scaling-SDN-Deployments-with-Onix.pdf', 'https://www.sdxcentral.com/networking/sdn/definitions/what-is-sdn-controller-south-bound-api-interface/']

Question Text: Which property guarantees that each RCP replica continues to install correct forwarding state in the network data plane, even in the case of a partition in the data plane?
Choices:
a. Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network that it is controlling, and therefore can guarantee consistent routing within that partition.
b. The controller cannot see many of the routers in the network anyway, so there is no way for it to install incorrect routing state in the routers that it is not connected to.
c. The controllers are partitioned from the network routers, and the routers will fall back to running a distributed routing protocol.
d. Running the network from a single high-level control plane guarantees that network partitions and loops never occur in the first place.
LLM Explanation: Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network it controls. This allows the controller to maintain consistent routing within its partition, even if the data plane becomes partitioned. The controller can continue to install correct forwarding state in the routers it has visibility of and control over.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 4: The Control Plane', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/sdn-definition/']
